posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I just reminded myself of what we all know - AI generated code can be dangerous!

I Google searched “java source code alpha beta filter” for fun (would a-b filter help the LL jitter or its outright bizarre poses?).

I got a complete program with a nice deterministic test case in main and an okay packaged function.

I copy/paste the “C” program in Wikipedia (ran it Java, though, with the deterministic test case) and ran the two head-to-head and the two answers were quite different.

I tracked down that the AI generated code had an error in one line of code (forgot to multiply by dt time step).

I did the Google search again to verify and I got a different program without the error (good) but without the test case (too bad - that could be better).

Did the search a third time and got another program with test main with random noise generator (like Wikipedia example - not so good to verify accuracy).

Fourth search had a nice touch on the function that allowed entering initial values for the test but still used random noise for testing.

A fifth time - same as the second time - correct filter function but no main to test and no initial parameters easily specified to use the filter function.

So seductive but I grade the four cases from fail to A-. You could make one good A program out of the four but it’s a lot of work if one of them is wrong!

posts.name: Nick Foote
posts.cooked:
The AI powering Google’s “search summary” function in particular is abysmal compared to other LLMs like Claude 3.5 Sonnet (currently the best at coding as far as my testing goes). I’ve completely abandoned Google Search when it comes to finding useful results.

If you’re looking for actually good AI powered searching, Perplexity is top tier, and cites it’s sources.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Nick Foote - 2102 Team Paradox - Engineering Mentor and Founding Student

posts.custom_user_title: Nick Foote - 2102 Team Paradox - Engineering Mentor and Founding Student

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Thanks for the information. Looks like Claude 3.5 Sonnet now costs money so I didn’t try it. Perplexity gave a good response and even threw in a couple of getters for the Java program. That test case could have included a few more test points but I rate the result an A. I recognized where almost all of the lines of code and explanations came from various web sites I looked at.

When you get search results like this, it’s hard to trust anything from Google’s AI search results: IMG_7565 720×1077 130 KB

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: My wife hates the search engines dredging up very old useless, confusing stuff. Maybe Google regrets just a little regurgitating that 12 year old glue post? Nah, but apparently they made yet another patch not to do that again.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Here’s one I could do today. Not dangerous or harmful, but it’s adding nonsense that wasnt needed or leaving out some critical piece of the sentence it thinks isn’t important.

Screenshot_20241208_194901_Chrome 1080×2316 187 KB

Screenshot_20241208_194901_Chrome 1080×2316 187 KB

Screenshot_20241208_194901_Chrome 1080×2316 187 KB

The website it grabbed this from is a Honda Dealership How to Jump Start a Car talks about how some cars may have a 6volt battery. Not that a dead cars battery will also be at 12 volts when it needs a jump. So imagine someone reading this though, thinking they need a multimeter first to check both voltages then refusing to jump the car because one is lower than 12…

link_counts.title: How to Jump Start a Car

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
kingc95:

some cars may have a 6volt battery

Aren’t you being a little harsh on Honda? /s Actually you worry too much. For example I got a new hybrid 11 months ago and the 2" thick stack of manuals still is gathering dust. I did have to look at it once a few months ago when the auto dim headlights that the salesperson told me to forget about wouldn’t dim and blinded an oncoming driver (who in turn blinded me). That reminds me - I have no idea where the battery is.
